title: Spinning binary waveforms via PN expansion: Equal-mass case

title_detail.value: Spinning binary waveforms via PN expansion: Equal-mass case

summary:
Complete expressions of time-domain gravitational waveforms for spinning
binary inspirals via the post-Newtonian (PN) approximation would require
determination of the phase, amplitude, inclination angle, precession phase and
spin vectors as well as the knowledge of the order coefficients for the PN
expansion terms. These quantities are determined by solving simultaneously the
spin-precession equations, the evolution equation for the Newtonian angular
momentum, and the equation for the orbital frequency. For the spinning binaries
with equal masses, determination of these quantities can be done fully
analytically, by taking advantage of the equal mass symmetry, therefore by
simplifying those equations to solve. We provide the analytical results through
1.5 PN order which includes spin-orbit interactions.

Complete expressions of time-domain gravitational waveforms for spinning binary inspirals via the
post-Newtonian (PN) approximation would require determination of the phase, amplitude, inclination angle, precession phase and spin vectors as well as the knowledge of the order coefficients for the
PN expansion terms. These quantities are determined by solving simultaneously the spin-precession
equations, the evolution equation for the Newtonian angular momentum, and the equation for the
orbital frequency. For the spinning binaries with equal masses, determination of these quantities can
be done fully analytically, by taking advantage of the equal mass symmetry, therefore by simplifying
those equations to solve. We provide the analytical results through 1.5 PN order which includes
spin-orbit interactions.

Arun et. al (author?) [1] provides the "Ready-to-use" time-domain gravitational waveforms for spinning binary
inspirals in Post-Newtonian expansion to 1.5 order. Their formulations, however, have yet to be further specified,
depending on the configurations of binaries, such as the mass ratio and spin alignment with the Newtonian angular
momentum. In order to make use of their theoretical waveforms in designing our wave templates via the IIR method,
it is necessary to solve the equations governing these configurations and to fully specify the waveforms with all known
parameters.

C.

Determination of the total phase and the amplitude factor
1.

The total phase

Arun et. al (author?) [1] defines the orbital separation vector n̂(t), which is set to lie along ~ex (t) at initial time,
i.e., n̂(t = 0) = ~ex (t = 0), and rotates on the plane spanned by ~ex (t) and ~ey (t) by the cumulative angle Φ(t). Then
one may write down the following two orthogonal vectors:
n̂(t) = ~ex (t) cos Φ(t) + ~ey (t) sin Φ(t),

(81)

λ̂(t) = −~ex (t) sin Φ(t) + ~ey (t) cos Φ(t).

(82)

We see that Φ(t) is the phase measuring how n̂(t) has rotated relative to the vector ~ex (t). For our precessing binary,
however, ~ex (t) is itself rotating about L̂N (= ~ez (t)), which is associated with the angles ι and α (see Eq. (27)).

 8

comoving basis ~ex (t) and ~ey (t), which is parametrized by Φ(t) and a rotation of the basis due to the precession, which
is parametrized by ι and α. Ref.(author?) [1] shows this in the following way. In the basis {n̂, λ̂, L̂N }, we introduce
an "orbital-like" frequency ωorb , which is defined as ωorb = (v * λ̂)/r. Then one may write
